awd_titl_txt: Disjoint Paths in Graphs and Coloring
awd_abstract_narration:
Many real word problems concern large systems that may be modeled by graphs. Those systems include communication networks, social networks,  and neural networks. To analyze those systems,  it is important to understand the structure of the underlying graphs, in terms of  the existence of certain structure,  connectivity,  and partitions. It is often the case that methods for studying graph structures lead to efficient algorithms. This project studies structure of graphs with certain forbidden substructures, as well as related problems on connectivity and coloring. This project also contains research problems that are suitable for students.  

Determining the chromatic number of an arbitrary graph is difficult. However, one might be able to obtain  a reasonable bound on the chromatic numbers of graphs not containing a given structure, such as subdivisions of a graph. The PI will work on an old conjecture of Hajos: Graphs without K_5-subdivisions are 4-colorable. If true, this would be a generalization of the well known Four Color Theorem. The PI will study the structure of such graphs, as well as its  connections to connectivity problems about disjoint paths in graphs, including a long standing conjecture of Lovasz on removable paths.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Real world situations can often be modeled as graphs. Fundamental research in graph theory may provide tools and results with potential applications.

The PI worked on a conjecture of Hajos that would give a generalization of the Four Color Theorem. The PI and collaborators obtained useful structures of a possible counterexample, providing insight to the understanding of the conjecture. The PI and collaborators solved two problems on classes of graphs with polynomial chi-bounding functions. The PI and collaborators also proved a number of results on matchings in uniform hypergraphs and developed an approach to study rainbow matchings. In addition, the PI and collaborators solved a problem on graphic Travelling Salesperson Problem.

A number of gradaute students gained research experience by working on some of the topics related to the project, and completed their PhD theses on those topics. Students presented their work at conferences and in seminars, some were invited talks.  

The project resulted in 16 research papers published in top combinatorics journals. 

1. J. Ma, T. Tang, and X. Yu,  subgraphs in iterated triangulations , Electronic J. Combinatorics 27 No. 4 (2020) https://doi.org/10.37236/9292

2. X. Liu and X. Yu, Number of Hamiltonian cycles in planar triangulations, SIAM J. Discrete Math 35 (2021) 1005--1021.

3. H. Lu, X. Yu, and X. Yuan, Nearly perfect matchings in uniform hypergraphs, SIAM J. Discrete Math. 35 (2021) 1022--1049. 

4. Q. Xie, S. Xie, X. Yu, and X. Yuan, in planar graphs and Hajos graphs, J. Graph Theory 98 (2021) 179--194. 

5. H. Lu, X. Yu,  and X. Yuan, matchings for 3-uniform hypergraphs, J. Combinatorial Theory, Ser A 183 (2021): 105489.

6. G. Liu and X. Yu, Partitioning digraphs with outdegree at least 4,  J. Graph Theory 98 (2021) 604--622.

7. J. Gao, H. Lu, J. Ma, and X. Yu,  On the rainbow matching conjecture for 3-uniform hypergraphs, Science China Math 65 (2022) 2423--2440.

8.  Q. Xie, S. Xie, X. Yu, and X. Yuan, Separations in Hajos graphs, J. Graph Theory 99 (2022) 485--508.

9. X. Liu, Z. Wang, and X. Yu,  Hamiltonian cycles in planar triangulations, J. Combinatorial Theory, Ser B 155 (2022) 256--277.

10. H. Lu, Y. Wang, and X. Yu,  Perfect matchings for 4-uniform hypergraphs, SIAM J. Discrete Math. 36 (2022) 1645--1662.

11. H. Lu and X. Yu,  A note on exact minimum degree threshold for fractional perfect matchings, Graphs and Combinatorics, 38:80 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00373-022-02475-1

12. M. Wigal, Y. Yoo, and X. Yu, TSP walks in subcubic graphs, J. Combinatorial Theory, Ser. B, 158 (2023) 70--104.

13. M. Wigal and X. Yu, Tutte paths and long cycles in circuit graphs, J. Combinatorial Theory Ser B, 158 (2023) 313--330.

14. H. Lu, Y. Wang, and X. Yu, Better bound on the size of rainbow matchings, J. Combinatorial Theory, Ser. A, 195 (2023) 105700

15.  X. Liu, J. Schroeder, Z. Wang, and X. Yu, Chi-binding functions for t-broom-free graphs, J. Combinatorial Theory, Ser B, 162 (2023) 118--133.

16. H. Lu, Y. Wang, and X. Yu, Co-degree threshold for rainbow perfect matchings in uniform hypergraphs, J. Combinatorial Theory Ser. B 163 (2023) 83--111.
